sadness.desc: We experience sadness with the actual or perceived loss of a person to whom we are attached, such as an offspring, a lover, close friend, or to a loss of our own health or social status to the loss of an object that we value highly.
sadness.statesDesc: There is significant overlap in the states of sadness compared to previous maps, but there is still a broad range of intensities.

disappointment.desc: Felt when expectations are not met, resulting in a loss.

distraughtness.desc: Agitated sadness. Felt intensly and often for long periods.

discouragement.desc: Felt when no way to cope with an actual or potential loss is known.

resignation.desc: Accepting that nothing can be done to prevent an important loss.

helplessness.desc: Realization of the inability to prevent or cope with loss.

misery.desc: Intense prolonged feelings of anguished sadness.

grief.desc: Anguished sadness aroused by the death of a loved one. Varies over time, from very intense at the time of the death to intermittent moderate as time goes on.

anguish.desc: Intense agitation. Protesting form of despair over an actual or expected loss.

actions.Withdraw: To physically or mentally leave the scene.
actions.Ruminate: To compulsively rethink about one's experience.
actions.Despair: To give up hope that there will be any recovery from the misery felt by the loss.
actions.Protest: To complain about the loss albeit knowing that the complaint will not recover what was lost.
actions.Feel Ashamed: To feel the need to hide how one feels about what or who is lost.

triggers: loss of health of a friend, lover or family member
rejection from anyone with whom one has a strong attachment

disgust.desc: We experience disgust in reaction to toxic smells, tastes, unappealing appearances or repulsive behaviors. While usually unpleasant, in small doses disgust may sometimes be enjoyable.
disgust.statesDesc: Disgust manifests generally as something fairly mild or very strong, with few states occupying the middle.

dislike.desc: An aversion to something, some person or some action.

distaste.desc: Offended by taste, smell, sight or actions.

repugnance.desc: Repelled by something toxic, literally or figuratively.

nauseousness.desc: Metaphorically denotes a very intense disgust reaction.

loathing.desc: Very intense disgust. Very objectionable to be the target of loathing.

revulsion.desc: Very strong disgust which usually implies a movement away from the source.

abhorrence.desc: Extremely repelled by look, smell, or taste of toxic substances, or by highly offensive actions.

actions.Withdraw: To physically or mentally leave the scene of what is triggering the disgust.
actions.Avoid: To either phsyically stay away from (someone or something); or internally keep one's mind away from what is triggering the disgust.
actions.Vomit: Literally to expel material from the mouth or stomach; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.
actions.Dehumanize: To treat someone as though he or she is not a human being' to deprive of human qualities, personality, or spirit.

triggers: religious groups usually not ones you grew up as part of
ethnic groups other than one's own
actions not typical of your own cultural group
anything coming out of the body

moods.name: sour
moods.desc: Not commonly a mood, it can occur as a mood when there is a generalized feeling of repugnance or revulsion - usually of low intensity.

anger.desc: We experience anger whenever our pursuit of an important goal is blocked, especially by a physical threat. In the grip of anger we may act in ways that we later regret.
anger.statesDesc: The anger continent includes states that respond to threats (real, imagined, or anticipated) or interference with pursuit of a goal.

annoyance.desc: The mildest state of anger never felt very strongly.

exasperation.desc: Losing patience with a person or task that is generating an overload of frustration.

frustration.desc: Feeling unable to achieve a goal you are seeking. Slight to moderate intensity.

bitterness.desc: The residue from having been angry repeatedly, because it seems that one is living in a world populated by people or events that block pursuit of what is important to you.

argumentativeness.desc: More likely to partake in unfriendly verbal disagreements.

vengefulness.desc: A  strong desire to harm someone who has harmed you.

fury.desc: Fury or rage names the highest most intense state of anger, often resulting in a loss of control. May result in violent actions.

actions.Dispute: Disagree in a manner that may escalate the dispute.
actions.Quarrel: Verbally oppose in a manner intended to escalate the disagreement.
actions.Insult: Disparaging the other person in a offensive or hurtful way, which is likely to escalate the conflict in a way that interferes with resolving it.
actions.Blame: To hold the other person responsible for the disagreement, (or more broadly, the conflict) which has developed.
actions.Undermine: To make (someone or something) weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.
actions.Scream/yell: Loss of control in how or what one says during a disagreement; speaking in a high volume, pitch and tone.
actions.Use physical force: Use of physical force to get one's way, which may be deliberately chosen or the result of a loss of control over how one acts.
actions.Set limits: Encapsulate the boundaries of disagreement, seeking to inhibit escalation.
actions.Be firm: Convey that one's position is strongly held, not likely to be abandoned.
actions.Withdraw: To physically or mentally leave the scene of the conflict or threat.
actions.Breathe: Focusing awareness on breating in order to diminish angry or fearful feelings.
actions.Take a time out: Announce intention to withdraw, to prevent escalation of the conflict.
actions.Practice patience: Regard the conflict as an opportunity to not lose one's temper.
actions.Reframe: To reconsider the trigger to the emotion to understand it in a different light, reducing or eliminating the perception that a threat is being triggered.

moods.name: Irritability
moods.desc: Irritability is a an angry mood. It is characterized by a readiness, a need to become angry, filtering perceptions to see provocations not noticed when not irritable. The cause is usually not known to the irritable person, but they may know that they are in such a mood. Frequent bouts of anger occur when irritable, which are more intense and last longer than they would when not irritable.

fear.desc: We experience fear when we perceive a threat of harm. Examples are threats to our health, wealth, social status, relationships, or identity/self-image.
fear.statesDesc: The fear continent includes states that respond to danger (real, imagined, or anticipated).

trepidation.desc: Mild fear, typically about something not immediate but pending.

nervousness.desc: Having or showing feelings of being worried and afraid about what might happen next.

worry.desc: Concern that something bad or harmful might happen.

anxiety.desc: Apprehensiveness about an impending or anticipated threat. It may also be used when a threat can be sensed but not specified in its nature.

dread.desc: Anticipating a severe threat from which there is no protection or avoidance.

desperation.desc: Driven to partake in risky attempts to reduce a perceived threat.

panic.desc: Extreme fear when no way to reduce the threat is apparent.

horror.desc: A mixture of fear and disgust which probably alternate quickly rather than merge together.

actions.Withdraw: To physically or mentally leave the scene of the conflict or threat.
actions.Avoid: To either physically stay away from (someone or something); or internally keep one's mind away from what is triggering fear.
actions.Hesitate: To hold back in doubt or indecision; to delay momentarily.
actions.Freeze: To become fixed or motionless; especially, to become incapable of acting or speaking.
actions.Suppress: To actively try to avoid feeling the emotional experience.
actions.Scream/yell: Loss of control in how or what one says during a disagreement; speaking in a high volume, pitch and tone.
actions.Reframe: To reconsider the trigger to the emotion to understand it in a different light, reducing or eliminating the perception that a threat is being triggered.
actions.Be mindful: To notice and accept the feeling of the emotion and recognize the feeling as temporary.
actions.Breathe: Focusing awareness on breathing in order to diminish one's fearful feelings.
actions.Ruminate: To compulsively rethink of one's experience.

triggers: a moving object about to impact us if we don't duck

moods.name: apprehensive
moods.desc: Expecting harm but not knowing how to avoid it. Perceive threats when they are not there, or magnify the seriousness of a threat.

enjoyment.desc: We experience enjoyment when a good feeling is generated, which we often seek to continue or re-experience.
enjoyment.statesDesc: Enjoyment has more named states in the English language than any of the other emotions.

relief.desc: When something expected to be unpleasant, especially the threat of harm, is avoided or comes to an end.

amusement.desc: Light, playful, humorous feelings of enjoyment.

excitement.desc: Energetic pursuit that, unlike other enjoyable emotions, is rarely felt slightly, but ranges from mid to high in intensity. May merge with any of the emotions to generate a very active form of that emotion.

ecstasy.desc: Rapturous delight. A state of very great happiness, nearly overwhelming.

fiero.desc: An Italian word that describes the enjoyment felt when you have met a challenge that stretched your capabilities.

naches.desc: The Yiddish word for the enjoyable feeling of pride in the accomplishments, or sometimes just the existence, of your actual offspring, or mentored offspring. Crucial for motivating the nurture of infants and children.

wonder.desc: Experiencing something that is very surprising, beautiful, amazing, or hard to believe.

schadenfreude.desc: Enjoying the misfortunes of another person, usually a rival.

rejoicing.desc: A warm, uplifting feeling that people experience when they see unexpected acts of human goodness, kindness, and compassion. Mild to strongly felt. Also called elevation.

compassion-joy.desc: Enjoyment felt when you act compassionately, especially if your actions help to relieve another person's suffering.

pride.desc: Wanting others to know the pleasure you feel in your own accomplishment or the accomplishments of another whom you either nurtured directly or identify with.

actions.Withdraw: To physically or mentally leave the scene.
actions.Maintain: To continue to do what is necessary to continue the enjoyable feelings.
actions.Gloat: To enjoy others envying your enjoyable state.

triggers: specific learned sensory pleasures such as a favorite food or song

moods.name: high
moods.desc: Generalized, non-specific feeling good not about any trigger; lasting hours

apprehensive.text: Afraid that something bad or unpleasant is going to happen; fear about the future. Can be slight to extreme intensity.

avoid.text: To stay away from (someone or something); to prevent the occurrence of (something bad, unpleasant, etc.); to keep oneself from doing (something) or participating in (something).

belittling.text: To describe (someone or something) as little or unimportant. Experienced by the target as insulting.

belligerent.text: Angry and aggressive; showing readiness to fight. Moderate to extreme intensity.

blissful\/high.text: An indescribable wonderful, unique enjoyment experience, typically brief in duration. Extreme intensity.

blue.text: Sad or unhappy; marked by low spirits. Slight to extreme intensity. Can also describe a mood.

calmness.text: A state of mind, not an emotion, in which you are best able to consider, reflect and use your intelligence.

constructive.text: Helping actions to develop or improve something or someone;

contempt.text: The last of the universal emotions to appear in child development, it is a feeling of moral superiority to the target. Often mixed with enjoyment. The evidence for the facial signal pan-culturally is very strong.

dehumanize.text: To treat (someone) as though he or she is not a human being; to deprive of human qualities, personality, or spirit.

destructive.text: Causing damage, destruction or harm; designed to hurt or destroy.

disagreeable.text: Not pleasing; unpleasant or offensive in manner. Easily angered or annoyed.

embarrassment.text: Darwin theorized it was undue positive attention, but faux pas also are causes of embarrassment. There is no facial or vocal signal unique to embarrassment. Blushing is the sign. Darwin noted that some people blush more than others, women more than men, and within families it is common for many members to blush. Dark skinned Africans blush but it is not visible or barely visible. For these reasons we do not consider blushing to be a signal, but a sign. There is some evidence that by a sequence of facial expressions and bodily movements, embarrassment can be signaled, but it has not received the crucial test of obtaining open ended judgments of what emotion is recognized when this sequence is observed.

emotion.text: A mental state distinguished from other mental states by not one but a set of characteristics, chief among them are: universality, distinctive physiology, distinctive subjective experience, involuntarily experienced as a result of very fast, automatic appraisal of events, inescapable, requires skillful practices to become aware of the emotional impulses before any action.

envy.text: Wishing for what another person has or does.

freeze.text: To become fixed or motionless; especially, to become incapable of acting or speaking.

gloating.text: To feel or express great, often malicious, pleasure or self-satisfaction.

guilt.text: Regret about a past action, which although the person recognizes they have acted wrongly, the motivation is to confess, believing that they may be forgiven. In guilt the disapproval is focused on the wrongful act, while in shame the wrongful act spreads to encompass the person

hesitate.text: To hold back in doubt or indecision; to delay momentarily. An action that may occur in fear, at least initially. Slight to moderate intensity

insulting.text: To do or say something that is offensive to (someone); to do or say something that shows a lack of respect for (someone). To treat with insolence, indignity, or contempt. Moderate to extremely intense

irritability.text: A mood saturated with anger. In which the trigger is often unknown.

jealousy.text: An emotional story line involving three people, a desired person, a rival, and the person feeling the jealousy. Jealous people may, depending on what they believe is occurring, may feel any of the emotions. For some people jealousy is very toxic. Envy is sometimes confused with jealousy, but it involves two not three people,, in which one person desires to have what another has, often believing the person envied is not deserving.

love.text: A strong attachment to another person, typically parent towards child and child towards parent, but also between those romantically committed. Commitment, although it can be broken by traumatic misbehavior of the loved one, is typically enduring. Within a loving relationship all of the emotions can at some point be felt.

hate.text: Anger focused on a particular person or group of persons, wishing the target misfortune, sometimes including a wish to directly harm the target. Hatred endures over time, and is corrosive to development, often generating a personality trait of hostility, characterized by an overabundance of anger, easily aroused towards any interference with goal pursuit.

mood.text: A slight but continuous emotion saturated state that makes someone less responsive to the changing nuances of his or her environment; rarely does one know why he or she is in a mood. Moods last for hours emotions endure for minutes. In emotions one usually knows what triggered it, at least afterwards, but the trigger for a mood often is unknown and unknowable.

ornery.text: Easily annoyed or angered. Can be an emotional state or a personality type

pugnacious.text: Showing a readiness or desire to fight or argue.

quarrelsome.text: Ready or likely to argue or disagree.

regrettable emotional episodes (anger an.text: These are actions or words that one regrets having engaged in. Rarely felt while those regrettable actions are occurring, but afterwards when consciousness/awareness comes into play reflecting on what one has done and why. Often it is the response of the target that brings the regrettable behavior into the person’s awareness. Characteristics of a regrettable episode: 1. Response is too weak, not sufficient to the situation. 2. Response is too strong, more intense than the situation demands. 3. There was no response at all, when the situation demanded some response. 4. The response is at the correct strength, but it is delivered in a hurtful way (if anger) or in an otherwise undesirable fashion. Any of these characteristics may combine. Usually a person is unaware of their intention, unaware of how they are acting, until afterwards. If awareness were to arise during the regrettable episode, the episode would be interrupted. Why do regrettable episodes occur? Because the person is unaware of the emotion that has been triggered and the destructive actions that have been activated. Regrettable episodes are typically manifest with the same characteristic, too strong or too weak etc., again and again. Remedies: To bring awareness to recognize the triggers, and if possible the impulses to actions before the action, or the type of action that is selected.

shame.text: Often accompanies disgust with one self, and the expectation that if others knew the offensive thoughts or actions, they would be disgusted. The motivation in shame is to never reveal the offensive thought or actions. There is no distinctive brief facial expression for shame. Sadness appears on the face, sometimes with the head turned away or hand covering part of the face. Shame is often confused with guilt, but they differ in that in shame there is self-loathing and motivation to never relevel the misbehavior. It is not just a wrongful act, as it is in guilt, but the self itself which is at fault. Guilt is about a wrongful action, acknowledgment of that wrongful act may elicit forgiveness.

spiteful.text: Having or showing a desire to harm, injure or defeat someone, especially because you feel that you have been treated wrongly in some way.

state.text: A condition of mind or temperament. We become emotional when something is perceived or anticipated which closely matches something that in the past has been important to our welfare.

surprise.text: The briefest emotion, triggered by the sudden occurrence of an unexpected event. It can be a way station, leading, after more appraisal, to any of the emotions.

time out.text: A short period of time when a child must sit quietly as punishment for behaving badly. In adult arguments a request for time-out can allow for reappraisal and reconsideration of the trigger and what action to choose.

trigger.text: Something, an event, memory or the product of imagination, matches a previous trigger, and by automatic appraisal then is converted into a trigger for an emotional state, and action.

uncooperative.text: Not willing or able to work with others or to do what someone wants or asks for.

undermining.text: To make (someone or something) weaker or less effective, usually in a secret or gradual way.

vomit.text: Literally to expel material from the mouth or stomach; metaphorically denotes very intense disgust.

withdrawal.text: Social or emotional detachment from a situation. Also, a pathological retreat from objective reality (as in some schizophrenic states).

uncharted.title: Uncharted Emotions
uncharted.description: Half or less than half of emotion scientists believe there is convincing evidence that each of the following is an emotion.

sections.title: love
sections.content: A strong attachment to another person, typically parent towards child and child towards parent, but also between those romantically committed. Within loving relationships, anger, fear, sadness, disgust and enjoyment all can be experienced.

sections.title: hate
sections.content: Enduring anger focused on a particular person or group of persons. Over time hatred may generate the personality trait of hostility.

sections.title: surprise
sections.content: The briefest emotion, triggered by the sudden occurrence of an unexpected event. It often is a way station, leading, after more appraisal, to any of the other emotions.

sections.title: contempt
sections.content: The last to appear in child development, it is a feeling of moral superiority to the target. Often mixed with enjoyment.

sections.title: jealousy
sections.content: An emotional story-line involving three people: a desired person, a rival, and the person afraid of losing the commitment of the desired person. During jealousy, anger, fear, disgust, sadness or surprise may be felt by any of the three people.

sections.title: envy
sections.content: Although often misused as a synonym for jealousy, envy involves resenting and wanting what another person possesses. When feeling envy, anger, contempt, or sadness may also be felt.

sections.title: embarrassment
sections.content: Activated often by praise from another, also by a faux pas. No facial or vocal signal, but a blush which is only visible in light-skinned people.

sections.title: shame
sections.content: Expecting others would be disgusted with you if they knew what you were thinking of or had done. It motivates a strong wish to prevent others from learning what you have done or thought.

sections.title: guilt
sections.content: Regret about a past action, which motivates the wish to confess the wrongful action, hoping for forgiveness.
